results:
Based on my search results, I found comprehensive information about the first Polish edition of "The Hobbit" by J.R.R. Tolkien. Here are the key details:

## First Polish Edition Details:

The first Polish edition of "The Hobbit" was published in 1960 by Iskry Publishers (Wydawnictwo Iskry) in Warsaw.

The translation was done by Maria Skibniewska, who created the Polish word "krasnolud" (dwarf) to distinguish Tolkien's dwarves from fairy tale characters.

The illustrations were created by Jan Młodożeniec, one of Poland's most prominent graphic artists and co-creator of the Polish poster school.

## Physical Details:
- 374 pages, [2], with 2 foldout tables
- Format: 13x20.5 cm
- Paperback edition with dust jacket

## Historical Significance:
This translation is considered canonical and classic. This was the third edition of The Hobbit in the world, following the original English edition and presumably one other translation.

After translating The Hobbit, Skibniewska signed a contract in 1958 to translate The Lord of the Rings with Czytelnik publishers, and she consulted with Tolkien himself during the translation process.

The search results also show that this first edition has become a valuable collector's item, with several antiquarian bookshops offering copies, some in luxurious leather bindings.
